{"status":"ok","message-type":"work","message-version":"1.0.0","message":{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,13]],"date-time":"2025-05-13T15:09:13Z","timestamp":1747148953857,"version":"3.40.5"},"reference-count":35,"publisher":"Wiley","issue":"3","license":[{"start":{"date-parts":[[2023,11,28]],"date-time":"2023-11-28T00:00:00Z","timestamp":1701129600000},"content-version":"vor","delay-in-days":0,"URL":"http:\/\/creativecommons.org\/licenses\/by-nc\/4.0\/"}],"funder":[{"DOI":"10.13039\/501100012163","name":"Universit\u00e4t Innsbruck","doi-asserted-by":"publisher","id":[{"id":"10.13039\/501100012163","id-type":"DOI","asserted-by":"publisher"}]}],"content-domain":{"domain":["onlinelibrary.wiley.com"],"crossmark-restriction":true},"short-container-title":["Health Economics"],"published-print":{"date-parts":[[2024,3]]},"abstract":"<jats:title>Abstract<\/jats:title><jats:p>What is the role of general practitioners (GPs) in supporting or hindering public health efforts? We investigate the influence of vaccine\u2010skeptic GPs on their patients' decisions to get a COVID\u201019 vaccination. We identify vaccine\u2010skeptic GPs from the signatories of an open letter in which 199 Austrian physicians expressed their skepticism about COVID\u201019 vaccines. We examine small rural municipalities where patients choose a GP primarily based on geographic proximity. These vaccine\u2010skeptic GPs reduced the vaccination rate by 5.6 percentage points. This estimate implies that they discouraged 7.9% of the vaccinable population. The effect appears to stem from discouragement rather than rationing vaccine access.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.1002\/hec.4781","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2023,11,28]],"date-time":"2023-11-28T16:15:52Z","timestamp":1701188152000},"page":"509-525","update-policy":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1002\/crossmark_policy","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":2,"title":["Vaccine\u2010skeptic physicians and patient vaccination
